page.title: 01CASTLE CARROCK & ENVIRONS
page.content: The study area lies at the foot of the north-western fringes of the Pennines. To the east the fells, heather-covered on their flat summits and bracken-covered on their steep slopes, rise to over 400 metres. Near the foot of these fells are the villages of CASTLE CARROCK and TALKIN. These lie on undulating ground formed at the end of the ice-age by the deposition of fairly sandy material. The river Gelt, rising on the local fells, drains the area. This river, which can rise rapidly after heavy rain, has cut a deep valley for itself, and is bordered by thick, deciduous woods. Most of the lowland is a mosaic of small fields, bordered by stone walls nearer the fells and by hedges towards the west.
